div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
ENGLAND AND JAPAN WORLDS RECEPTION OF TREATY ALARM IN RUSSIA
div.p: Paris, September 28 The French press has received the Anglo- Japanese treaty favourably, and it is believed that there is no reason why it should cause any ill feeling between Great Britain and Russia, and that the safety of Indo China is strengthened by the alliance of Japan with a power which is in excellent relations with France. (Reuter)
St. Petersburg, September 28. Article IV M the treaty is viewed with alarm here, and it is considered that it is open to the widest interpretation. (Reuter

Berlin, September 28. A few of the weighty German papers consi- der the treaty unobjectionable. The rest declare that it is most menacing and urge a Russo German counter alliance, of which it is believed that M. Witte's visit is the precursor. They advocate the inclusion of France in the alliance. (Reuter

St. Petersburg, September 28. The "Novce Vremya” says that the Anglo- Japanese alliance enslaves Asia, and that it is aimed particularly at Russia. It enables the allies to co operate either for the eventual annexation by Great Britain of part of Afgha- nistan or of Northern Saghalien by Japan, For these reasons Russia must counterbalance the treaty by a now alliance.
Liberal circles here welcome the alliance as tending to restrain aggressive policy, and to concentrate the attention of Russia to the improvement of the home situation. (Reuter

div.head: FRANCE AND GERMANY. AGREEMENT SIGNED.
div.p: Paris, September 28. The Agreement between Franco and Ger- many with regard to Morocco, which was signed at Paris to day, is virtually a confirma- tion of the agreement of the 9th July. The French are satisfied because it is considered to be a recognition on the part of Germany of the legitimacy of French colonial expansion. (R.)
Paris, September 28. M. Rouvier and Prince von Radolin have signed the Morocco agreement. The conference will meet at Algeciras. (Havas

div.head: THE CHATHAM EXPLOSION.
div.p: Port Said, September 28. The explosion of the Chatham blew the vessel to pieces and threw a huge column of water, sand, and debris 2,000 feet into the air. The East bank of the Canal is destroyed for a distance of 600 feet. The West bank is unda- maged It is impossible to state when the Canal will be opened for navigation, probably it will be after four days. (Reuter)

div.head: THE SUCRERIES. FURTHER DIFFICULTIES FEARED.
div.p: Paris, September 28. New financial difficulties are feared by the Sucreries. (Havas

div.head: M. WITTE ARRIVES IN RUSSIA.
div.p: St. Peteruburo, September 28. M. Witte has arrived. He was greeted very warmly. (Havas)
St. Petersburg, September 28. M. Witte had a long conference with Count Lamsdorff to day. (Reuter)

div.head: GENERAL STOESSEL ILL
div.p: Moscow, September 28 General Stoeasel has had a paralytic stroke (Reuter)

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB.
div.p: In view of the 3rd annual aquatic sports, members will please meet the handicapper at the Marina to morrow. Boats will leave the landing stage at 3 and 4 p.m. for the Khe divial Floating Dock.

div.head: ST. ANDREWS CHURCH, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The Sacrament of the Lord’s Supper will be Celebrated in this Church on Sunday next at 10 30 am. Visitors and friends are cordially invited.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES SITUATION- DEATH OF M. DE LA BOUGLISE
div.p: Our Cairo Correspondent telephones that M. de la Bouglise, while leaving a confec- tioner’s shop in the Sharia el Manskh in company with M. Laroux at 6.30 p.m. yester- day, suddenly staggered and fell. Medical aid was unavailing, death, which is stated to have been caused by heart disease having been instantaneous. The body of M. de la Bonglise was removed to the French hospital from which the funeral will start at 4 p.m.
The sad news caused considerable excite ment on tho Alexandria bourse this morning, the shares of the Societe des Sucreries falling to 45 from 50 frs.

Sir William Wilcocks has been appointed by Judge Tuck as the third agricultural expert to replace Nourisson Bey. The Societe des Sucreries is to be congratulated on its choice since it would be difficult to find in Egypt one more suitable in every way to fill this difficult and important position.

div.head: (By Telegraph).
div.p: Cairo, Friday 11.4 p.m. M. de la Bouglise, who has been suffer- ing from arteriscelerosis for a long time, died suddenly in Sharia Suliman Pasha from an attack of angina pectoris. His death was notified by the French consul yesterday evening.

div.head: THE PRINCES AND THE DAIRA. LETTER PROM Lord CROMER.
div.p: Our contemporary “Al Lewa” publishes an important letter from Lord Cromer to H.H. Prince Ibrahim Pasha Halim concerning the action to be brought by the Princes, sons of the late Khedive Ismail, against the Govern- ment claiming the restoration of the remaining surplus of the Daira Sanich after the satis- faction of all the creditors of the said admi- nistration, as being heirs of the former owner the late Khedive. One of the claimants, Prince Ibrahim Pasha Halim according to our con- temporary, wrote to ask Lord Cromer’s opinion on his claim. Lord Cromer's reply left no doubt as to his opinion ; he expressed his agree- ment with the view of the Coutentieux and after drawing the attention of Prince Ibrahim to the opinion he had given in 1878 when serving on the Commission of tho Egyptian Debt, vix., that the Daira properties had been illegally acquired, that their acquisition was prejudicial to the interests of the country and that the Khedive should restore the properties illegally obtained, he added : — “ I still maintain my opinion and regret to inform your Highness that not only am I unable to support your claim but that should the Egyptian Government be disposed to admit it, I would be obliged to protest in the most effective fashion in the interests of the Egyptian people and taxpayers.”

This excellent and uncompromising answer appears to have greatly annoyed our confrere, Mustapha Pasha Kamel, who calls upon the Egyptian public to show their resentment at the affront offered to the sons of the late Khedive Ismail and to support the demand of the princes for the restoration of their rights. We imagine that the Egyptian public will prefer Lord Cromer's advice to that of the "Nationalist leader” and Turkish pasha.

div.head: CHEMIN DE FER DE L’ORIENT.
div.p: We are informed that the number winning the first prize in the Chamin de Fer de l’Orient lottery is 41698, provided there is no error due to faulty transmission by telegraph.

div.head: ASILE KAISER WILHELM.
div.p: A concert was given on Tuesday afternoon at the Asile Kaiser Wilheim under the patronage of the vice-consul of Germany by Mme Meyer and her pupils and was very largely attended. Mme Tonelli, sister of the well-known Alexandria musician Professor Lombardo, also assisted, playing a duet with Mme Meyor which was very much appreciated and in which both ladies showed great musical talent. MM. Astorre and Michel Mabardi sang together in an excellent manner, and M- Amodio greatly pleased the audience by his rendering of a selection from the opera Aida which he played on the violin. M. Egon Mabardi recited excel- lently. We must also mention Miles Lea Ponta, Eveline Tonelli, Mario and Olga Philippides, all of whom performed their part of the pro- gramme most faithfully and showed a wonderful technical knowledge of music, although they are still quite children.

div.head: THE FAYOUM MURDER.
div.p: The "Bashkholi” ol Messrs. Green’s ezbeh with his brother, son, and daughter-in-law, the late M. Mataloti’s cook, and his ghaffir have been arrested with ten other arabs, who are believed to have aided and abetted the actual murderers, if they were not guilty themselves. The inquiry continues.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL.
div.p: Bulkily (near Alexandria) BAMLEH’s FASHIONABLE HOTEL PATRONISED BY THE ELITE.

div.head: THE CHATHAM EXPLOSION MR. HARRIS' GREAT SUCCESS WATER ASCENDS 500 YARDS. (From our Port Said Correspondent.)
div.p: Port Said, Thursday 2 p.m. I am now able to send you full details of the world's record dynamite explosion, which, as I telegraphed you as soon as the wires were in working order at 1.30 p.m., was successfully performed, and if I may be allowed to say so, reflects the greatest credit upon Mr. Harris. The divers, who bad been specially selected on account of their previous experience and because they bad been down all over the ship on former occasions, were on the scene last night as well as tags and material, so that all should lie in readiness for laying the mines at the first streak of dawn. Mr. Harris, his two assistants, Mr. Schmitt and Mr. Plata, Lieute- nant Cunningham and the interpreter, left here at 5 a.m. in the Albatross arriving at Ras el Esh at 5.45 a.m. where they dropped Mr. Plum who proceeded to kilometre 15.5 to prepare the north end of the firing wires and cut everything else. At Ras el Esh the party took on board two skilled telegraph wire workers and the vessel left at once, towing the dabsbeah, with the charges on board, after them, to the Chatham. The mines were made up in huge bolsters of sail canvas and each had two submarine detonators in them with about eight feet of cable attached, to which the submarine cable was to be connected.

Arriving alongside the Chatham the divers were at once sent down to open the hatches ready for lowering the mines into place, whilst Mr. Harris himself proceeded to attach the connecting wires. These wore each of 100 yards long and were, at the proper time, led ashore and fixed on to Nos. 2 and 4 telephone wires on the posts on the canal bulk. The joints were made most care fully, and in about half an hour the 300 lb. mine for No 1 hold was ready for lowering. The mine was put into a canvas hammock, the rings of which served as slings, All was now ready, and the charge was care- fully raised and put into a boat, which, in its turn, was taken under the derrick head with which the dahabesh had been specially fitted. The piece of cable which was to connect the mines in Nos 1 and 3 holds being attached, and the joint being covered with guttapercha, the mine was lifted by the winch and gently lowered to the divers who were standing on the trunk deck waiting for it, some 14 feet below the surface. Great care and gentleness was exercised in the lowering of the charge as it would have been absolutely fatal had the mine received the least shock, and after some little time taken in manipulating the awkward ‘baby’ it eventually, some 15 minutes later, lay resting on the cases of dynamite in the vessel's hold. To avoid any shock, the rope by which the mine was lower- ed, was then cut, and the dahabeah with its greatly relieved operators on board proceeded to the next hold to which the divers had already gone, whilst the cable which would complete the circuit between the two charges was enrolled from a boat. Before going any further the first shore line was sent away and tied to a post as it was not safe to connect in any way with shore lines until all the work on the Chatham had been finished.

The divers then opened np hold No. 3 whilst Mr. Harris went on with his joints and con- nections, if anything more carefnlly than before. All being ready at eight o’clock, the second charge was lowered in its hammock and placed in dose proximity to the case of detonators, which had been the Canal Company’s "bate noir” in the early days of this dangerous and most anxious problem. By 8.15 a.m. all was ready, and the boats were sent away to the tugs waiting some little distance north of the ship, and these vessels at once left for Port Said at top speed. Mr. Harris and his little select group then went about their final shore connections, whilst Mr. Tillier telegraphed to Port Said to hoist the signal which would tell the people of that town that in an hour, vix., at 9.50 a.m., the wires would be fired. In a few moments the wires were connected and the party left for the firing point where were assembled Mr. Tillier, Mr. Coallant, Mr. Doyen, Mr. Schmid, and Mr. Perrier, no one else being allowed within the cordon of sol- diery which had been drawn at an early hour at kilometre 3.1.

Arriving at the firing point, kilometre 12.52, the experts proceeded to test the wires, the result of which would prove whether the explo- -ion would occur or not, for were there the very least fault in the wires or connections the galvanometer would show at once the use- lessness of proceeding further, and the need fir at once lifting the charges anew and making new joints and examinung the whole length of three miles of wire. The galvsnomoter register- ed a force of 11, and with a sigh of great relief the party lit up pipes and cigars to await the appointed time knowing that the ship would go up the moment the twist exploder lever was put down.

At 9.45 a.m. the first wire was screwed on to the exploder and in four minutes the other wire was treated similarly, whilst the little party stood round, watches in hand, waiting the word from Mr. Tillier on whose time the order to hoist the Port Said signal was made. Precisely at 9.50 a.m Mr. Harris quietly took out his handkerchief and firmly grasped the lever, thrusting it down with all his force. Istant- aneously, and before he had taken his hand off the lever, a shock was felt as if the ground had been struck heavily in the near vicinity, and an immense column of water, sand, debris, stones, and pieces of iron ascended and con- tinued to ascend for five seconds, getting blacker every moment as the fragments in- creased in number. The column appeared at first like a huge fountain, and as it grew it assumed the form of an immense black tree with great branches. Up it went with great rapidity, growing in height, density, and volume, till 15 seconds after the explosion it had attained a measured height of 560 yards and had spread the width of the canal twice over. The water boiled and foamed, being scattered the while in a hundred ways all across the canal. The report, which resembled that of a 4.7 gun at a distance of say 500 yards, reached the firing point 16 seconds after the lever was put down and considerably surprised me by its feebleness. I think most of the other untechnical watchers, like me, expectated a much louder report and several of them remarked on the weakness of both sound and shock. Thirty-five seconds after the charges were fired, the greater part of the debris had fallen, but for fully two min- utes the sir was full of mist and the water above the remains of the unfortunate ship continued to boil up violently and tear up the banks of the canal. Whilst awaiting the train, which was in readiness with some 50 guests on board at kilometre 8, the party amused itself in trying to discover the extent of the damage to the canal, but this distance was too great and nothing was certain. No tidal wave accompanied the explosion though a current with a veloc- ity of about two miles an hour ran past kilometre 12 and back some few minutes after; nor did any debris reach the spot—both of which points Mr. Harris had declared himself sure of.

The train arriving shortly after, the party proceeded slowly fearing accidents to the wires at Ras el Esh where telegraph line staffs were stationed to get their lines at once in order. Slowly and carefully we went on to kilometre 18 and there stopped, finding the line smother- ed in grass, reeds, trees, telegraph wires, frag- ments of iron etc., and the country inundated, but rapidly drying, for some 1,009 yards round the spot.

With great excitement the guests and Mr. Harris' party left the train and crossed the fresh water canal by the bridge which had been erected the previous day, find- ing the fresh water canal intact, though very muddy and thick with weeds, grass, and trees. Arriving on the maritime canal bank walking became difficult. Wires, posts, pieces of ship's plates, beaxs, and frames were sticking up in all directions and the surface of the ground was under water in places, and muddy in the extreme.

No telegraph posts were actually down but all the wires were off the posts, lying about everywhere and covered with a thick coating of oxide. Along the African bank, which had not suffered in the least except for numerous and immense holes in the ground where the masses of water had descended, all was desolation and wreck.

In a circle of about 600 yards radius thous- ands of pieces of the ship lay in confusion and all the country had been covered deeply in water. Dead fish were plentiful and were secur- ed by the Arabs on the train.

The Railway staff at once proceeded to their survey but found no damage beyond a few loose bolts and the telegraph parties started at once to repair the damage to their lines. The Asiatic bank presented a truly awful sight with a huge hole driven into it of some 70 yards wide and 250 long, strewn with wreck- age and coke in a fine powder.

The fore end of the ship as far as abaft the engine room had completed disappeared, the mainmast in small pieces lay resting on what little remained of the poop and no signs were visible of anything else belonging to the ship except the hundreds of pieces with which the East bank and its environs were strewn.

Immense fissures were cut in all directions, the wreck lay everywhere in thick mud, half a mile way great pieces of engines and plates were standing sentry over the surronnding waste of marsh and desert. All was black from the coke dust and smelt strongly of nitro- glycerine, the fumes from which were contin- ually rising from what was left of the vanished but famous Chatham.

A hurried survey with the lead line was made before the officials and Mr. Harris’ party left for Port Said after their mostt anxious and tiring day. At the spot where the fore end of the ship lay -yesterday there were 22 metres of water. The depths varied from 20 to 15 metres and in the middle of the canal where originally 9 metres covered the bottom, only 6, or even less, could be measured. The shock had excavated hundreds of tons of mud and sand and deposited it towards the African shore.

Railway traffic was resumed this afternoon by 3 o'clock, whilst the State telegraph lines were repaired and in use by half past one and those of the Canal Company only half an hour later. Great relief is felt at the little damage which has been done and Port Said especially congratulates itself upon the escape of its fresh water supply from any interuption, as this was regarded as more than possible. It cannot be definitely said for how long the canal traffic will be delayed but I hardly think that a clear passage will be obtained for another ten days. I shall, however, be able to tell you more when I have learnt the results of the soundings which are, at the time of writing, being taken. Tags, divers, sounders, and dredgers are all on the spot and the Canal Company officials are displaying the same activity which they have shown ever since the boat caught fire on the 5th inst Mr. Harris, upon whom the respon- sibility of the carrying out of this experiment lay, mast indeed be pleased with the result of his work, and fully deserves all the con- gratulatory terms which I hear on every side, whenever his name is mentioned, which is not seldom.

div.head: (From Another Correspondent.)
div.p: A remarkable example of the terrors of the unknown has been affurded by the scare created in Port Said by the blowing up of the Chatham which was successfully effected shortly before ten o'clock. Shops in the town remained unopen, people left their houses in fear that they would collapse, and in a variety of other ways showed their dread of the effects of the explosion. And yet when it did take place, even the sound of it in the still morn- ing air was so dull that it might well have passed unnoticed by any one not expecting anything out of the common. Seated on a chair placed on the frail covering of the water tank on the roof of the Eastern Exchange and exposed to the foil glare of a burning sun, with eyes or glass fixed on one spot, the time of waiting, seemed long. The signal flag was hoisted on the Canal Company’s offices a little before nine o'clock. The hour struck, all of us, (about a dozen) were gazing intently on the distant landscape, but the minutes went by, the chimes told the quarter-past, half-past,and a quarter to ten without the least sign of anything having happened. But directly after wards two or three steam launches were seen to be rapidly coming in the direction of Port Said and it was evident that the moment for which we were eagerly waiting was at hand. At seven minutes to ten a huge gray column slowly rose and spread out like a tree, disap- pearing again in the space of a few seconds, almost before the dull muffled sound of the explosion was heard. This column rose to an enormous height impossible to estimate, and consisted of water and sand, though it looked more like smoke. Not the slightest earth tremor could be detected and the water below us was not in the least disturbed.
I understand that little more than I have described was experienced by those who went by the special train and who were unable to get any nearer than five miles from the scene of explosion.

Altogether the damage done has been far below even the minimum estimate and it seems to be only a question of the removal of the wreckage of the ship and the time in which this can be effected, before the traffic of the canal can be resumed. The present estimate is that it will take about three or four days only.

div.head: ( By Telegraph. )
div.p: Port Said, Friday, 9.22 a.m. The following were present at the electric generative station at kilometre 12 yesterday:— iMM. Coallant, Tillier, Diyeo, Jasserand, Schmitt, Lieutenant Cunningham, Mr. Harris and his two assistants. The first wire was connected at a quarter to ten exactly, the second at 9.49 a.m. and the explosion took place in less than one second after Mr. Harris had pressed the lever of the twist exploder. In one second the column of water had risen to a height of 100 yards, in eight seconds it measured 400 yards and in twelve seconds a height of 550 yards was reached. Then the debris was seen to rise in great masses, and pieces of iron weighing more than a ton were thrown into the air as high as half a mile. The mixture of water, sand, and debris continued to rise for thirty five seconds. It is anticipated that further explosions will be necessary to complete the destruction of the vessel. Prompt measures were taken by the Canal Company officials towards repairing the damage done. At two o’clock sounding and repairing gangs, engineers, divers, and dredgers were hard at work and careful surveys were being made. The length of time for which the canal traffic will be interrupted cannot be estimated accurately until the report which the engineers make as a result of their survey is to hand, but it is generally anticipated that it will be a week. Mr. Harris, however, considers that ships will be able to pass through in safety in less than a week's time.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.H. The Khedive remained at Montazah to-day and attended Friday prayers at the Montazah Mosque.
H.E. Coles Pasha, C.M.G., inspector general of the Prisons Department is returning to Egypt by the Bibby liner Cheshire leaving Marseilles on the 6th proximo.
Sir Elwin Palmer will arrive in Cairo on Tuesday next from England.
Mr. K Speir, the newly appointed secretary general of the State Railways, will arrive in Cairo from England on the 4th October.
Mr. John Perret has been appointed surve- yor of the Zifta circle of irrigation at a salary of L.E. 18 per month.

The P. and 0. Persia leaving Marseilles to- day for Port Said is bringing out a good number of well known residents amongst whom are Sir Malcolm Mellwraith, H.E. Crookshank Pasha and Mrs. Crookshank, Schalch Bay, Mr. and Mrs. C. Snow, Mr. and Mrs. Hooker, Captain MoMnrdo, Mr. and Mrs. Noel Beyts and the Misses Beyta, etc.

div.head: PASSENGER LIST. DEPARTURES.
div.p: La paquebit Perro), de la Cie Fiorio Rubat tino parti bier pour Genes avait a bord : Mlle Simmer, M. Catalafago, cap. Silvestri, M A Capua, M. Charon, M. Fechox, M. Max Jabaties, Willie Betts, M. N. Ferri, M. John Stevens, M. P. Sorionte. M. R. Leoni, M. J. Watson et IS passagers de some classe.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET (From our Financial Correspondent).
div.p: London, September, 22. The dominating factor during the earlier part of the week has again been the money market and the question as to what action would be taken by the dimeters of the Bank of England at their meeting yesterday was dis- cussed. Opinions were fairly evenly divided respecting a rise in the Bank rate but three discount houses which accepted six months Bank bills at 2 1/2 have proved correct in their anticipations rather than those which declined them under 3 2/5, for no change was made of the directors yesterday, the weekly return showing a stronger position then was expected. The Bank rate therefore remains for the present at 3 %. The opening of the markets yesterday shows that this was pretty well anticipated before midday with the consequence that there was a more cheerful tendency all round, and prices generally hardened. Consols, which we quoted last week at 89 13/15. have been up again to 89 7/8, and today close at. 89 9/25 This upward tendency has permeated all other gilt- edged securities, and they may be said to be on the advancing tack again.

Foreign Government bonds gained renewed strength on Continental buying. Japanese stocks were in special requests on a report which comes from a creditable source that Japan is already rewiring large amounts of money in respect of the Manchurian railway. The new loan is quoted at 4 7/8 Russian bonds have been firmer, it being reported that M. Witte has had an interview with Messrs Rothschild. Baron Hottingner, and Herr Pisehel. of Berlin, for the purposes of raising a "Peace" loan. The situation is considered favourable for the launching of this shortly, and it is believed that the loan will be offered in France, Germany, Belgium and Holland, but not the United States.

In the Home Railway market, increased traffics, the result of the steady improvement in trade, have produced a hardening tendency in prices. The amalgamation of the Great North of Scotland Railway with the Highland Railway, which is now on the tapis, and will probably be consummated era long, is looked upon favourably. The Amarican market has been stronger throughout the week, and Pacifica have taken the lead again. Not with- standing that the bulls have been taking profits, the shares have steadily risen, and it is predicted that they will shortly reach 200.

There is little to report regarding, move- ments in the Egyptian share market generally. Stocks have been quite inactive since our last, with, if anything, a slightly easier tendency. It is expected that the new Bank of Abyssinia, is about to make its appearance under the auspices of the National Bank, and, although nothing definite is yet known of the exact nature of the issue, it is favourably spoken of. It is believed that the last issue of New Natio- nal Bank shares was with connected with the Abyssinian venture. National Banks close to-day 27 7/8 and Agricultural Banks 14 5/8.

The only news to hand since our last with reference to the Societe de Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypt is that the accounts show a loss of L.F.213,000 over a period of ten months to the end of August last. In this is not included a deficiency of £920,000 which must be added to the former sum in the event of the Company being declared responsible for the bills drawn by M. Cronier. Daira Sugar shares are still quoted 4 3/4 and Daira Sanieh 27 7/8. Some business has been taking piece in the 1/2%. Preference shares of Walker and Meima- rachi which are quoted at 3 3/4 to 4 1/4. , In the mining market, the week has ended with a slightly firmer tendency in prices, and in the Rhodesian market Bankets are well maintained at £4. Mr. Garthwaile’s report, whilst not entirely optimistic, is looked upon with more or less favour as giving a tree version of the real state of affairs in the Banket section.

In the Egyptian mining market, Nile Valleys have slightly eased off since last week, and are now 1 3/16. ‘'Vigilant," in "Truth," says regard- ing these:—“Nile Valleys are being favourably influenced by a cable announcing that good rich ore has been located at the 200 feet level, the extent and value of which has not yet been ascertained. This is pleasant reading bearing in mind the discouraging developments of the past month or so.”

New Egyptians have also been easier at 1, whilst 15/ is the beet price for Egyptian Mines Exploration. Egyptian Estates and Egyptian Trust are also quoted at lower figures. United African Exploration, the mother company of several Egyptian ventures, have improved in price to 1 1/4.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: The following is the menu of the dinner at the San Stefano Casino tomorrow evening on occasion of the small dance. Consomme double glare Soles fritos Sauce Pommes nature Quartier d’agnean cultivateur Oband-foit de Poulardes Pelle vus Asperges en Brancho Cailles de vigne retic Salade de Salson Fruite Dessert

div.head: ARISTEN AERATED WATERS
div.p: Guaranteed Distilled.
